nested-commands.name: nested-commands
nested-commands.description: Include all nested commands in the output.

hour:add.description:
Passing no arguments will start an interactive session.

This command will add to existing hours. If run twice the hours will be logged doubly.
examples:
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %>
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> -H 3
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> -H 3 -p INTPD999DXD -t 01
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> -H 3 -p INTPD999DXD -t 01 --date yesterday
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> -H 10 -p INTPD999DXD -t 01 -d today --force
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> -H2 -pINTPD999DXD -dtoday --note "Onboarding meeting"

taskDetail.name: taskDetail
taskDetail.description: The task details (in it's short version, e.g. 01)

project.name: project
project.description: A project code (it it's short version)

date.name: date
date.description: [default: today] The date for which to log (can be human-readable)

force.name: force
force.description: Force logging more than 8h on one workday

hours.name: hours
hours.description: The number of hours to log (1h: 1, 30min: 0.5, etc.)

note.name: note
note.description: Note to be added alongside the hours

hour:edit.description:
If a day is specified, you will edit that days hours.
If a week is specified, you will be able to pick a day to edit for.

Examples of specifying a day : today, yesterday, fri, 5/25
Examples of specifying a week: this week, last week, 2 weeks ago
examples:
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> # today
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> -d "last fri"

$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> -d "this week"
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> -d "last week"

date.name: date
date.description: A date to specify the day OR the week (can be human-readable)

date.name: date
date.description: A date to specify the week (can be human-readable)

short.name: short
short.description: Show shortend titles for the projects (for smaller terminals)

hour:remove.description:
If a day is specified, you will edit that days hours.
If a week is specified, you will be able to pick a day to edit for.

Examples of specifying a day : today, yesterday, fri, 5/25
Examples of specifying a week: this week, last week, 2 weeks ago
examples:
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> # today
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> -d "last fri"

$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> -d "this week"
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> -d "last week"

date.name: date
date.description: A date to specify the day OR the week (can be human-readable)

note:add.summary: Note down what you worked on.
note:add.description:
Passing no arguments will start an interactive session.

This will add to existing notes for the same day.
examples:
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %>
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> -n "This and that" -p INTPD999DXD
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> -n "This and that" -p INTPD999DXD -t 01 --date yesterday
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> -n "Worked 5h with Node" -H5 -pINTPD999DXD -t01 -dtoday

taskDetail.name: taskDetail
taskDetail.description: The details of a task (in it's short version, e.g. 01)

project.name: project
project.description: A project code (it it's short version)

date.name: date
date.description: The date for which to log (can be human-readable)

hours.name: hours
hours.description: Hours to be logged alongside the note

note:edit.description:
If a day is specified, you will edit that days hours.
If a week is specified, you will be able to pick a day to edit for.

Examples of specifying a day : today, yesterday, fri, 5/25
Examples of specifying a week: this week, last week, 2 weeks ago

It will ask you to change your note in your $EDITOR (in your case: nvim).
examples:
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> # today
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> -d "last fri"

$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> -d "this week"
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> -d "last week"

date.name: date
date.description: A date to specify the day OR the week (can be human-readable)

date.name: date
date.description: A date to specify the week (can be human-readable)

If a day is specified, you will edit that days hours.

Examples of specifying a day : today, yesterday, fri, 5/25
Examples of specifying a week: this week, last week, 2 weeks ago
examples:

$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> -d "last week"

project:add.description:
Passing no arguments will start an interactive session.

Copy paste the values from Oracle.
A project code will look like this: INTPD999DXD - People Development DXD
And the task details will like this: 01 - Career development
examples:
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %>
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> -p "INTPD999DXD - People Development DXD"
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> -t "01 - Career development" -t "03 - Discipline Weeks" -p "INTPD999DXD - People Development DXD"

project:edit.description:
Allows for renaming a projects or their task details.

It will ask you to rename in your $EDITOR (in your case: nvim).

full.name: full
full.description: Show the full list of task details

project:remove.summary: Remove a project or a projects task details interactively.

ticket:add.description: Create a ticket to be matched and expanded in note-taking.
examples:
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %>
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> --id AAKKK001-1337
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> -i AAKKK001-1337 -t 'The status icon "New" and the filter behind it should be adjusted.' -p INTPD999DXD

ticket:edit.description: Edit the id or title of a ticket.
examples:
# edit interactively
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %>
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> --id AAKKK001-1337
# edit title
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> -i AAKKK001-1337 -t 'The status icon "New" and the filter behind it should be adjusted.' -p INTPD999DXD
# edit id
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> -i AAKKK001-1337 --new-id BBJJJ002-1337 -p INTPD999DXD

new-id.name: new-id
new-id.description: New identifier for the '--id' to be changed to

project.name: project
project.description: Project to filter the tickets by

examples:
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %>
$ <%= config.bin %> <%= command.id %> --id AAKKK001-1337 -p INTPD999DXD

timecard:generate.summary: Generate a report for filling out timecards.
timecard:generate.description:
It will interactively step through one project after the other,
going along with you while you copy over data into Oracle.

date.name: date
date.description: A date to specify the week (can be human-readable)
